Yum! Dark brown pour - not too thick, not too thin. Big fluffy tan head with tons of lacing. Roasted malty nose. Rich taste and mouthfeel. Bitter chocolate and floral hops in the taste.

0.5l bottle from Whole Foods Tribeca. This is a deep dark brown one, almost wanting to call it black in the glass and it has a nice big and really lasting brown chocolate top. Chocolate is the best word I can use to describe the aroma on this. It smells absolutely fantastic chocolaty and sweet. Milky chocolate blended with the darker more bitter kind and it has cocoa tones as well. Im stunned how this brewer manages to hit that accurate good-spot in my nose time after time. It has lovely rich oily almost thick mouthfeel with a soft prickling carbonation level. Again, chocolate is the word here. Tastes like chocolate milkshake with a really good a pint of good grassy green hops. Smooth and so integrated flavors. A little bit of vanilla ice cream, chocolate, cocoa, mocha and coffee. Really stunningly nice this one! 20.06.2013

Bottle shared by Dr Silverworm. Poured a dark brown color with an average frothy light brown head that mostly lasted with fair lacing. Moderate toasted sweet chocolate malt, hop and small alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy toasted malt sweet flavor with a medium complex dark malt sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Solid complex brew.

16.9oz bottle, thanks to Mike L. Bottled December, 2012. Shared with tmoney99. Dark brown color. Good thin light brown head. Nice dots of lace. Bigger body. Lighter, crisp, lightly soft carbonation, with a more dry finish. Good chewiness to the body. Nice bigger bitter hoppy taste, light sweetness. Very hoppy, for a porter.. Some resin, pine, spicy and citrus hops. Big bitter very dark chocolate, light roast, some oats. Just a very light bite to the taste, is the only fault I can find for this. Excellent malt profile, and a nice big healthy dose of quality American hops. Great hoppy bitter dark chocolatey porter.
A big, persistent head rests atop this dark brew. There is a good deal of complex coffee and malt flavor, and a dash of something sharp in the finish. A very fine porter.

500 ml bottle.  Pours pitch black with a big frothy head that fades very slowly and leaves some webbing.  Aroma is creamy chocolate, roasted malt, musty hops, and light ash.  Taste is creamy and hoppy.  Bitter chocolate, light roast, and grassy hops.  Thick, chewy, and creamy mouthfeel.  Overall, its solid but a little too creamy and thick for me to love.

My bottle [500ml] shared with HogTownHarry, jercraigs & mabel -- c/o Glouglouburp. Pours a very dark brown, almost black, with an average size diminishing frothy beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and lots of leafy hops. Flavours the same, lots of leafy hops and roasted malt, with a big bitter finish -- simple but pleasant. Medium bodied. Pretty good.

Thanks to bu11zeye for sharing this bottle. The beer pours a brown color with an off-white head. The aroma is full of chocolate and roasted malt. The flavor is similar. I get some chocolate up front as well as some roasted malt. There is also a strong smoke character with a bit of ash coming through. Thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation.
Bottle from Halftime Beverage. Dark brown, red hues, tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, some light mint. Taste is similar, roasty/hops flavor.

Bottle, 6 months old. Black pour with brown highlights, massive tan head and super lacing. Aroma is chocolate, burn toast with a subdued grassy background. Taste is roasted grain, chocolate and earthy hops. Silky and puffy mouthfeel which makes it highly drinkable. Great porter, tasty and easily drinkable. Id be curious to try fresher for a more intense hop presence.

Bottle split with wingman DW at Tonys, from the Beer Shop LTD, 20/05/13.
Mid black with a mahooosive tan head.
Nose is little subdued, roast malt, grain, dark toffee notes.
Taste comprises a good mineral bite, hop backnotes, touch of chocolate, light roast.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, light roasty finish with a hoppy bite.
Decent porter.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle from...damn I forget. Pours out a very attractive brownish, almost black color with a big tan head. Aroma is of roasty coffee, chocolate, light bitterness. Taste is complex, nice chocolate notes, medium roast coffee, light earthy notes, silky smooth mouthfeel, light touch of bitterness in the finish. Have yet to be let down by a Maine beer.

Pours a very dark brown with thick brown head and good lacing. Aroma of piney hops, roasted malts, light smoke and chocolate. Taste has grassy hops, coffee, roasted malts, light smoke, honey, little sweetness and a fairly dry finish. Medium to low body and medium carb. Good porter!

Real nice porter. Pours almost black with a thin tan head. Lots of suspended particles floating about. The aroma is loaded with chocolate, coffee, roast malts and a hint of smoke. The flavor follows, nicely balanced and quite drinkable. Finish is smooth and tasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(500ml bottle)  Pours an opaque black body with a small tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, light coffee, and some lactose.  Flavor of chocolate, roasted malt, earth, grass, and caramel with a dry finish.

Bottle thanks to a trade! Pours a dark brown with a grayish brown head that dissipates slowly to the edges and laces. Aroma has roasted malts and sweet dark grains with a nice sweetness underlying. Flavor starts with sweet dark grains and a sweet chocolate that are joined by coffee and roasted malts.
Hoisted in Walts honor.   Dude, I didnt know yah. I didnt even really ever talk to yah. I read yer posts, and read a few of your ratings.  This ones for you.

(500ml bottle thanks to mar) clear medium dark brown, soapy dark tan bubbles that are thick and lasting. Nose of almonds, honey, toasty chocolate malt. Taste of medium rich chocolate malt, honey, toasty, oily body.

2013-05-24. Black body nice foamy tan head. Aroma is pleasant, modest roast and green hops. 7+ Flavour is similar, lots if roasty dark malt up front, modest green hops grows in the finish. 7++ Average plus bodied palate, modest carbonation. 3+ Pretty enjoyable. Bottle Shared by Blankboy

Bouteille 500ml. De couleur noire-brune et opaque. Nez de malt rôti, de chocolat noir, moyen de houblon herbeux, légèrement résineux et aux notes fruitées (agrumes), léger de noix avec des notes de pain brûlé, de caramel et de café. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen-doux ainsi quune texture moyennement crémeuse et aux notes huileuses. Goût de malt rôti avec des notes de café et de pain grillé dès lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute rapidement un léger-moyen goût de chocolat noir avec des notes de caramel et quelques traces de tabac. Parallèlement, une légère-moyenne amertume de houblon herbeux et légèrement résineuse se développe jusquen finale où lon y décerne également des traces de noix. Post-goût plutôt long et un peu sec, moyennement amer de rôti, de houblon herbeux aux notes résineuses, léger de chocolat avec des traces de café.

Bottle. Pours deep reddish black with a medium brown head that dissipates slowly leaving nice lacing. Aroma is typical for the style - roasty with notes of coffee, cigarrettes, perhaps cocoa. Flavor is about the same, light sweetness and light to medium bitterness with a touch of acidity on the finish. Medium plus body, creamy mouthfeel. Pretty nice beer.

In a bottle (12/20/12). Fantastic. Espresso dark pour. Nice chocolate and toffee notes. Chocolate continues on the tongue. Quite malty with a dry lingering finish. Dark fruit in the back, but the malt rules supreme here. Quite nice.

Bottle acquired via trade with Thedrooid...thanks Dan!  Mahogany pour with chestnut edges and a small latte head.  Dark chocolate, brown sugar, burnt caramel, roasted malt and a touch of vanilla.  Silky smooth mouthfeel.  Delicious!

500ml bottle shared by blankboy with me, jercraigs.  Deep ruby-brown, solid creamy tan head.  Nice roasty porter nutty aroma, quite herbal.  Taste - a little harsh, a bit vegetal, roast, generic bitterness - okay.  Average body, a bit slick, decent bitter finish, quite dry.  Good.

Nice black pour with a thick tan head. Nose of nicely roasted malt, chocolate and brown bread. Medium mouthfeel, a bit chewy, but thats ok. Quite a sweet start (reminder of lactose) blends into a nice lingering dark chocolate style bitter finish. Not a stout, but definitely at the high end of the porter. Quite delicious, Well done MBC!

5 ounce sample at the Freeport tasting room.  Burnt caramel and licorice.  Bit of hops...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle sample at state line tasting..aroma is really top notch on this with quality coffee..espresso and dark roasted goodness center stage..pretty enjoyable from a quality newcomer to the scene..finish is slightly underwhelming compared to the nose..should be able to increase production with recent change of digs to a larger space in Freeport

Very solid imperial porter, and quite classic for this style. Dark pour with ephemeral brownish head. Strong roastiness, and quite chewy. Bitterness starts half way in, if not sooner, and sees you through. No gimmicks here. Like the label -- indeed like the state of Maine perhaps -- just honest goodness. Knows its not a stout, respects the boundary, and is gimmick free. Recommended! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle (500 ml). Black with a medium slowly diminishing beige head and heavy lacing. Aroma is of both dark & milk chocolate, roasted malt, caramel notes, slight citrus, slight herbal presence. Taste is slightly to moderately sweet with chocolate, caramel, roasted malt, slight citrus and some bitterness. Thick body for a 7,5% abv Porter. Oily/creamy mouthfeel. Rich and complex Porter. Drinkable. Not far from Everett at the top!

bottle.  lightly hazed dark cola brown body with a fine-bubbled tan head.  malt-driven nose of roasted grains, black patent char and burnt potato starches; mildly hoppy / fruity nose of dried grass and light citrus.  inky char flavor is an overdose of roasted malt astringency with light to medium sulfur but pleasant toasted oat character; mostly dry body, seems pretty well fermented out at 7.5%, so the bitterness comes across as excess, and with the pasty yeast its a all a bit too chalky and muddled.  I do like the depth of the chocolate malt and the oatmeal especially, theres a lot of good burnt brownie and cookie dough malt play here, and though no smoke, the char-heavy malt does remind of campfire.

Bottle, pretty fresh. Pours a pretty thick looking black with an enormous beige head. Aroma of cocoa powder, some roast. Taste is powdery, chocolate milkshake, slight roast, no real hop bite detected. Pretty good, but a little too sweet and not enough ass to mouth to get me excited.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown body with a rather large frothy light brown head that slowly fell and left some sticky lacing.  The nose is thick and intense with lots of chocolate and roasted maltiness, a little caramel sweetness, and a fairly hefty hoppiness for the style.  Smells very thick and intense, a slight touch of tobacco as well.  The flavor is equally intense and robust.  Lots of bitter chocolate and slightly burnt roasty malt up front, more bitterness from the hops mixed with some burnt caramel and coffee on the finish.  Not sure I love the bitterness of the hops with the burnt notes from the malt, they dont exactly play real well together.  Quite a bit more roasty than usual for the style.  Medium bodied and a bit chewy body with soft fizzy carbonation.  An interesting beer for sure.  I wouldnt hesitate to order a pint of this in the future.
Well-balanced cocoa, coffee, roasted malts. Lingering earthiness that rounds out the finish very well. Terrific.

Bottle courtesy of AirForceHops.  Smoky chocolate coffee aroma. Black brown with a ginormous creamy tan head, thick rings of lacing, great retention. Dark roast coffee, chocolate, ash, and light acidic flavor with a lingering roasty/earthy bitter finish.  Body on the light side of medium, moderate carbonation. Very nicely done.

Hats off to Pat for sending me this! Nice black pour with two fingers of head. Good retention on the head. The smell is bits of chocolate, hops, and some coffee to round it out.  The taste is hoppy, with a black coffee finish. A really nice porter.
Beautiful pour: black body, stubborn tan head, sticky lace. Big, viscous body. Roasty and dry; hints of coffee. Finishes with dry porter yeast. Pretty nice.

Bottle at RBJG#2 - Grand Tasting Tims Place. Black - offwhite head. Lovely fresh coffee, burned, acid, nice fresh, ok bitterness, hard burned, licorice, chocolate, dark malts, light sweet notes. Lovely.

Bottle - Pours black with a huge bubbly root beer float type of head. Nose is chocolatey, ashy roast, a bit of milkiness, molasses, and brown sugar. Definitely not on the sweet side--the dry ashiness is most prominent. Taste is dry and roasty, with a bit of boozy sharpness, some dark chocolate, and some bitter, grassy hops. Medium-bodied, but with a smooth, milkshake fluffiness.
Bottle from whole foods fair lakes - pours cola with a roasted chocolate nose. Palate is on the dry side. Overall,  nice!

Bottle from whole foods fair lakes. Pours black with an inch of khaki foam. Nice chocolate roasted notes on the nose. A little thin at first but seems to thicken up as it warms. Big chocolate on the tongue. Very Nice!

011813 bottle date

Pours a nice rich dark brown with a frothy milk chocolate head.

Aroma is mostly chocolate with a toasty char, a bit of residual sweetness.

Damn this is a smooth silky porter.. Big chocolate with a bit of roast, medium bodied with low carbonation. Finishes suuuper mellow and creamy, slightly dry and a hint of lingering roast but it doesnt bomb out your palate.

Always happy to pick up some Maine Beer when Im on the coast, I would be reaching for this as my go-to porter if it landed in MN.

In short: A creamy and hoppy porter with a bit of many things.  Good.
How: Bottle 500ml, consumed fresh a little more than one month after bottling date.
The look: Near black body topped by a large tan head with medium retention leaving lots of lacings on the glass.
In long: Nose is relatively hoppy (for the style) with pine-tree & wood resin almost dominating the burnt toasts and coffee.  Taste is burnt black cake, molasses, vanilla, tree sap, some baked dark fruits, some fresh tobacco.  A solid woody/coniferous bitterness that doesnt go overboard, this is a well balanced beer.  Body is thick and somewhat oily giving a motor-oil sensation.  I really cant find anything wrong with this beer (it is a Main Brewery beer after all) but yet the whole thing just didnt win me over like most Maine Brewery beers do, it was only good.  Overall, a good beer from this fine brewery who give back a portion of their sales to environmental groups around the world, these guys make me feel guilty for all the water I have wasted pretending to wash my hands after going to the washroom because there are people around.

Une bière embouteillée le 18-01-2013.  Une robe qui fait le style.  Un col qui simpose et qui reste figé.  Au nez, quelques notes vertes et résineuses  qui secouent une base maltée caramélisée et chocolatée.  Au goût, des saveurs de café qui se greffent à du chocolat, du caramel et à des notes rôties.  Un caractère houblonné qui me semble ici plus effacé.  Une impression en bouche bien confortable.  Un pétillement plutôt bas et une texture passablement riche.  Une finale amère de grains rôtis avec des petites notes terreuses et un murmure dacidité.

50cl bottle.  Large tan head atop cola black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, cocoa, some roast, grapefruit/earthy, light coffee.  Taste is moderately sweet, cocoa, some earthy/grapefruit, coffee/roast.  Medium body, light acidity, goes down quickly.  IMO, this borders on an imperial porter.

Bouteille de 1pinte 9 onze. Born on 01/18/13. Liquide brun foncée avec une belle mousse brune. Le nez complexe offre des effluves de café, de chocolat et de houblon herbeux. La bouche est passablement amère. Les houblons sont bien présents. La finale sue le chocolat est superbe. Merci Patrick pour cette trouvaille.

Bottle from Katbirds Wine. Bottled on Jan 18, 2013. Pours a dark brown, near black. Aroma is rich with notes of wafers, chocolate, pine, espresso. Very well balanced flavor with hops coming out, but not taking away from the malt body. Good coffee type notes with a dark chocolate finish. This is a very good, strong American porter.
Bottle: pours dark black with a thick, frothy tan head, aroma of coffee and chocolate, taste is chocolate, malty, dry finish, very nice porter

Bottle from the Thirsty Dawg.  I was a little concerned as the bottle was about 6 months old but it was still great.  Pours black with a thick tan head.  Caramel and chocolate aroma is subtle.  The mouthfeel is great, very creamy.  Taste of chocolate malt with a bit of smokiness and pretty big bitterness at the end that lingers a bit which would be the only thing I would change.  This is a great porter.

500ml bottle from Spirits Berkely. Poured a good looking medium density dark black with a large frothy beige head that leaves gobs of lace all over my Weyerbacher tulip. Aroma was a bit subdued, or my nose is a bit more stuffy then I thought, dark toast, burnt vanilla extract, marshmellow, and a hint of old burnt coffee beans. Medium to lighter mouthfeel with stronger carbonation and a hop bitter harsh finish. Flavor is nice with lots of roastiness, burnt malts, dark chocolate, vanilla extract, cold espresso beans. Nicely done porter.

Whole Foods, Bowery 50cl ($8): Pours blackish with a brownish head. Aroma is chocolate, artisanal coffee, roasted malt, and a few other things that I cant quite place. Taste is bitter dark chocolate, something that resembles tea (yeah never really had that in a porter before), some minor sweetness, and some sort of piny hop bitterness. An interesting and well made porter.
500 ml bottle. Thanks to UDBeernut. Creamy with chocolate and a nice roast profile. Hoppy all around. Tasty.
A well balanced, light, clean (??) Porter. Not too sweet and certainly less than roasty, this occupies a happy middle ground. Chocolate, hop bitterness some candi floss.

This one poured a medium brown color with a beige head. Aroma was light cutrusy and green hops, medium roast and some light chocolate. Flavor was. Very similar, very well integrated and creamy, great balance of hops, roast, and sweet malt. These guys are great brewers.

#800. Pours jet black with a thick tan foam head. Lacing coats the sides of my glass. Nose of roast, chocolate, and caramel. Taste follows this theme with food balance. Slight citrus on the finish. A slight chalkiness hangs on the palate post finish. Body is solid and has a creamy element.

Nose of dark roast and floral herbal piney dank hops. Some spicy hop notes and light chocolate underneatg. Rather hoppy almost like a black ipa. Pours almost black w a tan head.  Flavors of roast and dark chocolate and a good dose of spicy herbal and floral hops. Some citrus is there along w soft caramel sweetness and more dry roast.  Body seemed more in line e black ipa as well. Tasty beer. A hoppy porter.

Pours black with a light brown head that disappears slowly and leaves very nice lacing. Aroma is faint molasses and smoke with a light to medium body that has a creamy, rich, chocolaty, and roasty flavor. Nicely balanced. Really tasty!

From the 500 ml. bottle dated 011813.  The pour is jet black with a tremendous, soft mocha head that sticks around the entire time. Impossible to see through. The carbonation bubbles erupt like one of those nitro cans. The aroma is full of coffee, dark baking chocolate, and dark malts, with a more subtle clean hop note. It has Porter all over the nose. The body is medium to full.  The flavor is not quite as in-your-face chocolate/coffee but there is more of a dark cherry or dark fruit kick.  The finish has a low bitterness that lingers momentarily.  Really nice.

From the April 2013 3R6P beer tasting. +++ Sampled from a 16 oz brown bottle this beer poured a black color with a medium sized soapy brown head that faded quickly and left a bit of lacing. The aroma was toasty, faint coffee, vanilla and cocoa. The flavor was dryish and toasty with hints of molasses and vanilla and a bit of smoke. Medium length dry toasty finish. Medium body. Ok.

16 oz bottle to snifter (shared with the Mrs.; thanks jtclockwork).  Looks good; a very dark brown (almost black) with foamy beige head.  Smells and tastesw solid; dark malt and chocolate.  Nice and smooth on the palate.  A great example of the style.
Bottle at RBJG 2 Grand Tasting, thanks Travlr. Black colour with a small beige quickly vanishing head. Aroma of coffee, dark malt. Flavour is chocolate, malt.

16oz bottled November 25, 2012.  Served at cellar temperature.

Pours black with a one finger brown head that leaves some nice sheets of lacing and holds a persistent cap.

Aroma is heavy on chocolate, milk chocolate, bakers chocolate, cocoa, semi-sweet chocolate chips, some coffee, nice roasted malts, decent bit of dark fruit, a whiff of cardboard, some caramel, toffee, little to no hops.  Very good strength.

Flavor is roasted malts, some chocolate but not as much as in the nose, coffee, caramel, toffee, some dark fruit, a little cardboard again, earthy hops, light alcohol, somewhat astringent.  Astringency fades as it warms and opens up.

Mouthfeel is medium-plus bodied, pretty creamy, a little sticky, good carbonation.

Really nice Porter, one of the better ones Ive had.
Bottled. Cloudy black with lace. Nose of coffee, chocolate, licorice, citrus hops. Woody, coffee flavor, cola. Light and clean.
dark brown color, dark fruit, dark chocolate a touch of smoked cheese. Smooth, moderately dry, lingering dark chocolate finish.

Pours a deep mahogany with a surprisingly big, tan head.  Aroma is big and great: roasted coffee and dark chocolate.  Flavor is the same.  This porter has a great mouthfeel.  A really tremendous beer. To this point, this is my favorite brewery that Ive discovered in 2013.

500ml bottle in an English pint.  Pours very dark brown with a lacy, tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, hints of coffee, and a good amount of hops for the style.  Flavor a nice blend of the dark malts with a decent amount of hops.  Thicker texture.  A really good porter.

500ml bottle shared by jsprime. deep brown with a tan head. nice roasty malt nose with the hopping also showing. great flavour progression from the complex malt body to the hopsnear the finish. great porter.

Near black with a khaki head. Inviting chocolate and caramel aroma, some oatmeal and coffee are also involved. Roasty, a touch of tobacco and leather come in to play on this one. Creamy mouthfeel, tight carbonation. Has a tough mineral quality to it, reminds me of some english porters in that regard. Bitter finish. Not bad at all.

500 ml bottle courtesy of jtclockwork. Thanks. Pours an opaque dark brown color with a huge monster tan head that has good retention. The aroma is medium strong with chocolate, mocha and earth. The taste, like the aroma, features dark chocolates, mocha and earth. The palate is thick and creamy with soft carbonation. Finishes long, dry and leaves some lingering burnt toast flavors. Overall: My second brew from these guys, and its a good one too. This brewer rocks and deserves some hype.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2013 Another great offering from Maine Beer Co. Pours deep dark brown almost black with nice off white head. Aroma is chocolate, slight coffee, and pine. Taste is roasted coffee and chocolate. Also well balanced with nice bitterness from the hops. Really enjoyed this beer

Pours a deep brown, almost black hue with a thick, long lasting, frothy, slight of white head.  Aromas of toast, chocolate, with a dry, pleasant hoppy/ cleaning agent smell.... interesting.  mouth feel is 
edium bodied with flavors of coffee, pine, citrus and a touch of vanilla and roasted nuts.   Pretty hoppy for the style.
500 ml - chocolate notes abound. Chemical notes on,  nose a little scary. Lacing good color great,  flavor good

Dark pour with a tan head. Aroma is chocolate, roasty malts, light caramel malt, and dark fruit. Thick, dry, powdery mouth feel. Flavor is full of caramel and chocolate malt, some dark fruit, vanilla, and a bit of earthy hops. Real good.
Bottle. Pours dark brown nice head. Tastes smells of ash chocolate caramel very slight roasted coffee. Its a bit thin and not over top on bitter which is a nice change. Very good stuff.

Bottle.  Pours opaque black with a large, creamy and frothy tan head, long retention with excellent lacing.  Aroma is dark chocolate and roast malt with earthy coffee and hops, prunes and dates.  Flavor is malt dominant with medium hops and bitterness, dark fruity esters, faint vanilla with a dry finish.  Full body and medium carbonation.

Bottle at Sanders place in NYC. Pours dark brown with a strong, tan foam head. Deep, dirty coffee on the nose, good roast. Medium sweet flavor, big and dark roasty malts, bittersweet cocoa. Medium bodied with fine, massaging carbonation. Moderately sweet finish, robust cocoa, light burnt earthy bitterness, coffee. Great beer. Wonderful balance.

Serving: 500 ml. bottle from State Line Liquors.  It pours black with a large, creamy, dark tan head.  The nose is rather mute save slight cocoa powder notes.  The flavor has light roast, bakers chocolate, and light mineral notes with a slightly chalky mouthfeel.  Medium to full bodied with a lingering roasted malt finish.  Quite enjoyable.

A deep dark porter with a thick lacing dark brown head. In aroma, a nice rich chocolate malt with milk, coffee, toffee, very nice. In mouth, a smooth bitter chocolate with light caramel, coffee. grassy notes, nice. Bottle from Healthy Living, 5.99$, tasted Feb 8 2012.

Bottle from Julios. Pours out a very dark brown color. Thick, foamy tan head. Complex, malty aromas. Flavor is superbly balanced. Lots of layers of chocolate, slight bit of vanilla with a nice bitterness on the backside. Super smooth. Velvety and not fizzy. Goes down like a glass of chocolate milk! I am not a big stout and porter fan, but this is top notch!

This is dark colored with a thick fluffy tan head pouring on top.  Good lacing.  The aroma is a little ashy at first; with notes of oats, vanilla, and chocolate following.  This is slick and creamy with a roasty bitterness on the back end.  The flavor shows coffee, toasted oats, dark chocolate, and a little caramel.  Theres a nice hop character here too without it being too dominant.  Another winner from Maine Beer Company!

Appearance: near-black, with two fingers of thick, creamy, dense, rocky tan head that lasted forever and left rich swathes of cotton-candy lace everywhere.   Aroma: 	BOOM!  Bitter dark chocolate, fresh pine, espresso, mint, earth, and hope.  Taste: bittersweet cocoa powder, with resinous, chalky-dry hops, café mocha, roasted coffee beans, and a hint of toasted black bread, with just a whisper of a lactic tang/acidity.   Finish: smooth and nicely dry, with lingering dark chocolate and piney hops vying for attention.   Notes: Ive been on a major porter kick over the last few weeks, and darned if this is isnt the greatest porter Ive ever had.  Big, rich, chocolatey, and bittersweet, with a chewy but not overpowering palate.  Hops all over the place, but they add just the right amount of aroma and bitter character without overpowering or making it a hop-bomb.  I would drink this every darn day.  Phenomenal.  Hope I can find more.
Reviewed from notes.  Thanks, Chris! Roast and chocolate aroma. Fairly balanced. Flavor is similar. Carb a bit too high. Slightly acrid finish. Okay.
Bottle from Oak Tree. Pours black with tan head. Nose and taste of roasted chocolate malt, roasted coffee, roasted black malt, sweet cocoa and vanilla. Finishes very dry roast. Medium body.

This beer is cray.  Extremely hoppy robust porter with rich chocolate and roast character, strangely I like this more than most Black IPAs, perhaps because the hop character isnt super evident in bitterness, only in the up front flavor.
Two finger head, dark creamy brown head, initial chocolate aroma then something sweet, cocoa flavor with oily mouthfeel and a alcohol finish.

Truly fantastic.  Extremely well balanced and easy to drink while being super hoppy.  Its got a lot of roasty malt, hazelnut, a little chocolate.  Theres hops all over it as well, but they strongly accent, without dominating.  Bitter piney, a bit of resin.  The carbonation is very fine, and it goes down with a moderate finish.

16.9 oz. bottle from Village Market, Hampton Falls, NH. $6.50. Aroma is bitter chocolate, coffee, and generous amounts of pine hops. Solid flavors of dark chocolate, coffee, caramel, wood and the pine hops that I smell. charred notes. On the hoppy side for a porter. Dry texture with lingering pine and Earthy bitterness.  A very nice brew, job well done.

Do whats right says this beer under the ape mascots photo. And at a phenomenal 99 overall score, they did. Chocolate cake, smokey strong  coffee and even some hearty hops shine through on the aroma. A jet black color, tan lacing. Taste of bitter coffee and cigars, with just enough alcohol bite to let you know its there. Heavy body, though not sludgey, it is certainly filling. Great beer for a cold winter morn.

Pours a five+ finger brown head that fades very slowly leaving some lace. Black color, no highlights. Medium carbonation and medium-heavy bodied.  Bakers chocolate nose and flavor is baked chocolate and coffee. Decent porter. $7.75 for a 500ml bottle from Berts Better Beers Hooksett, NH

Location/Date:Bottle on February 9th, 2013.
Appearance: Pours a dark opaque with light red head.
Aroma: Aroma of roast, faint chocolate, boozy.
Taste: Roast, light bitterness, chocolate. Balanced.
Palate:Medium light body, light fizz, smooth.
Summary: My fifth beer rating from Maine Beer..and I continue to be amazed at the flavors in these beers have without being aggressive or inaccessible. Truly good beer.

Bottle. Black pour, tan head, little retention/excellent lace. Aroma of dark chocolate, roast, coffee. Taste is chocolate, roast, some hop bitterness, espresso. Palate is soft, creamy, light bitter finish.
amazing, dark porter, thick head, thick chocolate, thick spreen, dark, very smooth and goes down well, enjoy

Coffee, chocolate, and licorice in the aroma.  Flavor starts slightly sweet with coffee and chocolate, then finishes with some piney bitterness, almost like a cross between a porter and an IPA.  Not what I expected, but still good.

Bottle.  Pretty much black with a orange tan head, partially lasting with a little lace.  The aroma starts milk sweet, has a moderate roast and potent spicy, piney hops. The flavor is also more hop forward that a classic porter with bitter chocolate, tangy espresso, stronger roast, and bitter finish.  The mouthfeel is a standout. Its full and lively with a heavy citric linger.  Its certainly a great beer but goes more towards an American stout than I prefer in a porter, American and Robust or not.

I love stouts/porters and this is one of the best I have had. Creamy head. Fantastic aroma of chocolate.  Really smooth. they are fast becoming one of my favorite breweries. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle, poured into a snifter.  Pours black with a 2 finger mocha colored head. Heady aroma with bitter chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla and a hint of coffee. Flavor is initially on the bitter side, but turns sweet as you get into it. More chocolate and coffee. Full palate. Very nice porter!

It poured a very dark, browish black and left the same color body. A beautiful foamy lumpy mocha colored head appeared and lasted for a good minute. Some lightly speckled lacing appeared around the sides of the pint glass. No carbonation was seen rising due to the dark body, only one ring at the top of the pint glass, I like it. The smell had the coffee up front with some light tobacco chocolate in the background. The taste was basically the same, nothing really different. The palate was about a medium and a very nice smoothness and creaminess on the tongue. Overall, Im very impressed and would definitely come back to this.
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Bottle. Black pour with tan head. Some hop and roasted and sweeter malt aroma tones. Dark roasted and lporter malt flavors with lighter hop spiciness. Smooth mouthfeel.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt , dark chocolate, hops, & some coffee; Flavor of roasted sweet malt, coffee, caramel, hops, and dark chocolate; Very nicely balanced; Wow - excellent porter!

Bottle. Pours black with a lingering fluffy khaki head. Aroma is mostly chocolate. Taste is immediately sweet but quickly changes to bitter hops and roasted malts. Nice full mouthfeel. Very complex and off the beaten path for a porter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bottle dated 01/18/13. Jet back with a one finger mocha head that dissipates quickly. Smells of roasted coffee, chocolate, and a little dank hops. Taste is roasted coffee, bit of smoke, chocolate.  Nice mild finish and medium body.

Bottle... Clear dark-brown pour with a mahogany shimmer and a small, creamy, taupe head. Good retention. The aroma offers malty notes of brownies, toffee and toasted nuts. Full-bodied and silky with restrained carbonation. The flavor is decadent, supplying rich notes of mocha and caramel. It leans sweet, but a moderately bitter finish keeps thing in check. Great stuff. landhoney generously shared this beauty!

Bottle from Gianni - thanks!  Black pour with a large, rocky head of dark tan foam.  Aroma is dry, bitter chocolate, roast, wheat, underlying coffee, and background hop bitterness.  Taste is roast chocolate with light coffee and hop bitterness and a very small amount of sweetness.  Clean, dry, and precise mouthfeel.  Excellent understated and clean porter.

Brune opaque aux reflets rougeâtres, surmontée par une belle mousse beige, dense, capiteuse et persistante, qui laisse une dentelle baveuse aux parois. Arômes de grains grillés, de torréfaction, de café et de caramel. Goût moins imposant. Des saveurs davoine et de café noir constituent les principales caractéristiques. Cest moins rond en bouche que ce à quoi on pourrait sattendre. La texture est veloutée alors quune amertume appropriée se prélasse. Merci Louis. (Embout. 27 oct 12) (505-030113)

Bottle from Capones Restaurant.  Pours thickish black, with malty roasty aroma.  Above average and smooth mouthfeel.  The taste is great, very drinkable malty just right not too roasty.  Hits the bullseye.

Richmond 19th. Black, aroma is very coffee.  Flavor is similar, with a bit of chocolate, and a touch of a pepsin hoppy note.  More stouty than porterish. These guys are really good, one of the best of the tasting.

Bottle shared with Mdaschaf.  Roasty aroma, nicely balanced between chocolate and piney hops.  Black color, ample tan head.  Taste follows nose, with chocolate, good bitter hoppy bite but with a a really nice, roasty pervasive malty backbone.  Medium body, moderate carbonation,  medium-length roasty finish.  Overall:  An unexpected and delicious treat.  Thanks to Mdaschaf for sharing this!

Bottle. Black pour with a tall, dense, frothy brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, dark chocolate, soft piney hops and caramel notes. Taste is big roasted malt, caramel, pine, light floral hops, dark chocolate and soft brown sugar. Body is medium with a strong, bubbly carbonation and a moderate stickiness. Ends with more roasted malt, sweet malt, dark chocolate, chewy caramel, soft pine and mint chocolate notes.
Pours dark brown with a tan dissipating head.  Smells of roasty malt, light pepper. Tastes of chocolate, roasty, some dark fruity undertones. Enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours very dark brown  with a light cream head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee with hints of licorice. Taste is the same with a bit more licorice than i personally like. Nice creamy mouthfeel, but could definitely use a bit more bitterness to balance things out.

50cl bottle: pours an opaque obsidian with a creamy froth of dark beige head. Has a rich dark caramel and chocolate malty nose with generous amounts of fresh resiny hops. Starts with good fullness and chewy malty sweetness with lots of juicy hop flavor and bitter balance before a drier roasty dark chocolate finish. Full of flavor and dangerously drinkable.

Aroma of delicious cocoa, mocha, and vanilla.  Pours black with a hug biege foam head.  Taste is roasty good.  Burnt chocolate, coffee and a sweet milk behind it all.  Not too thick.  This is a great porter.
Chocolate and citrus aromas. Pours black with a tan creamy head. Predominately chocolate flavors with citrus on the back end. Overall a very good porter.
Tar nose, maybe prunes. Dark chestnut, thin yellow heads. Bitter charred oak, potting soil.
RG 19. Bottle. Dark brown with foamy ram head and light lacing. Smells like coffee and a hint of vanilla. Lightly toasty flavor, dry finish.
From the bottle poured a dark brown brew with a tan head. Malty aroma. Full bodied with flavors of malt, coffee and hops.

Half liter bottle shared by tia at the 19th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering. Pours a dark brown color with a thin frothy tan head. Good head retention. Aroma of rich roasted malts, chocolate, mild herbal hops. The taste is dark chewy roasted malts, herbal hops, nutty notes, big chocolate notes. Medium-full bodied. Damn good beer.

Bottle->snifter.  Deep brown with substantial tan head.  Aroma: coffee and roasted malt with an interesting sour hops note.  Taste: roasted malt, smoke, dark fruit, bitter chocolate.  Good porter, and definitely out of the ordinary for the style.
From a bottle poured a brown color with a small amount of head.  Light toasted malty flavor with a quick finish.

Bottled December 30, 2012.
Appearance: What a beautiful looking porter, the thick and foamy brown head leaves a thick layer of foamy lacing as it slowly dissipates, the lacing almost looks as if theres still head there. The head settles into a foamy coating that sits on the black body, brown is seen through the edges though.
Aroma: Sweet cocoa is the first thing that comes to mind which is balanced really well with a roasted coffee aroma, hints of caramel support the cocoa and roasted aromas.
Taste: Roasted coffee and dark chocolate are strong and intense right away on the intro giving an unassuming bitterness that shocked me after smelling the aroma. On the next sip the flavor are a tad mellow and I can pick up some light caramel flavors, but the dark chocolate and coffee are the primary flavors here.
Palate: Velvety smooth and thick body with no carbonation to note in the body.
Overall: This is an excellent porter that is well worth the price of admission. This is perhaps one of the best porters Ive ever had. The body really sets this off for me, its so thick and velvety, well done.

Black pour orange to beige head with sticky lacing .... aroma of dark chocolate, roasted and citrusy/piney hoppy as heck ...... taste is of dark chocolate, roasted and bitter with a nice piney, citrusy hop bite .... dry bitter hoppy finish .... excellent ... abv hidden well

Very nice brew.  Pours deep dark brown with a fluffy tan head.  Aroma is full of burnt malts, chocolate, and coffee.  A little thin, but very smooth and creamy.  Finishes slightly bitter, but full of flavor.  Well balanced brew, will drink again for sure.

500ml bottle at Proletariat in NYC. Excellent appearance, darkest brown in color with a medium sized but lasting tan head. The aroma is great with bitter chocolate, roast, and hops. What an effing flavor on this brewski - high quality artisan dark chocolate, sharp roast, charcoal, and a hoppy but not too bitter bite. Almost perfection. Smooth yet biting on the mouthfeel with medium-full body. Damn dogg! This is a great beer.

Pours dark unclear with a big creamy beige head and quite nice lacing. Aroma brings coffee and roasted nuts so nicely with a tad of herbal hops. The delicious and creamy body brings flavor of roasted malts and earthy hops that blend so well and go down smooth on the palate.

Dark brown pour with an off-white head. Nose is roast, ash, and char. Somewhat chalky, a little bit of cocoa powder, coffee grounds, and a light acidity. Strong roasted malt and ash character to the flavor, too. Coffee grounds, dark chocolate, chalk, and a light bitterness. Minimal sweetness and a definite acidity.
Bottled. Dark brown to black pour with tannish head. Roasty aroma. Roasted malt taste and bitter chocolate. Pretty good.

Location: .5 L bottle from Buy Rite, 12/31/12, Rating # 2700 will most likely double as my last rating of 2012, so lets call this a Happy New Year beer!  Looks like Ill wrap this year up at 689 ticks, maybe Ill crack 700 next year, or maybe not


Aroma: The nose is roasted malts, chocolate, pine hops, toffee, and some earth

Appearance: Pours a dark brown-black color with a thick, creamy brown head that leaves lots of lace

Flavor: The taste is malty up-front, not super sweet, mostly roasty, with a later dry-roasted bitterness

Palate: The body is medium-full, it feels creamy and smooth, with a fairly soft carbonation, and a dry finish

Overall Impression: 
This one is right up there with the best Porters I can remember trying.  The mix of roasted malts and hops works well, and exemplifies exactly what this style is capable of.  Since they only seem to make a few beers, but they make all of them rather well, Id say the good folks at Maine Beer Company have a keen understanding of quantity over quality.

Pour out of 500 mL bottle, thanks Aaron! Dark brownish black pour with nice tan head, aroma brought notes of cocoa, earthy and pine forward hops with a nice espresso tone, hints of a caramel, toffee middle as well, vanilla comes through as well.  Taste is a nice mix of sweet vanilla, cocoa, dark chocolate, roast, espresso, hints of earth and pine, slight citrusy sweet, finishing fairly bitter, dry.  Nicely done.
Once again yet another extremely well-made beer from Maine Beer.  Pours beautifully and tastes like a porter should with a bit of bite and a bit of cream.  Drink.

500mL from ChurchKey thanks to GT! Thanks GT! Poured a really stark, dark brown color with a tan head. Aroma is a bit mild, roasted malt notes, some notes of pine hoppy character. Cocoa and coffee. Pretty enjoyable.

16.9 oz bottle.  Pours a dark cola with a medium sized tan-light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, dark chocolate, oats and light charr.  Taste of roasted malt, oats, prunes, dark chocolate notes and charr.

500mL from ChurchKey for $16. Okay, I love this brewery so its worth it. Pours a clear, deep sepia to blacker. Thick, rocky, massive mocha foam. Big lacing. Nose is hoppy, piney, sappy, some strawberry ice cream, raw animal. Taste is cherry, sugar, pine, semisweet chocolate chunk, coffee/dark chocolate/lemon acid. Sessionable, fluffy body. Lactic acid balance. Simple, delicious. Can go no wrong here.
UPDATED: JAN 13, 2015 Wow this is some tasty stuff. Very deep rich thick body, Black roasted malts, dry finish. This is great stuff by a great brewery.

16.9 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a smooth beige head.  Nose is coffee, cocoa and hay; soft but rich.  Silky and creamy, melts away to a tang with a clean resiny bite.  Taste is coffee bean, dark chocolate and pine with hints of licorice and earth.  Luscious and sexy then brash and spicy.  Reminds me of Thisted Limfjords.

500mL bottle, sent from Glouglouburp (thanks Dany), pours black with a creamy light brown head. Aroma is dominated by oats, with some dry cocoa powder and feint black coffee notes. Flavour is very robust for a porter, with the oats dominating, followed by dry cocoa powder, and more of the oats. The finish is, again, dominated by the oats, as well a hint of coal. A highly drinkable, simple, but well-constructed, robust porter. Great stuff.

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of Aaron. Thanks man!! Pour is hazy deep brown  with a big brown head and great lacing. Earthy hops, pine, cocoa, coffee, bread, rye, vanilla, and oak in the aroma. Taste is  dark chocolate, vanilla, wood, spice, caramel, and toffee with a medium bitter finish. Medium mouthfeel with high carbonation. Super smooth and hoppy porter; really tasty stuff. Thanks buddy!!

Bottle @ Stephens house, courtesy of Lukaduke. You are neato, Luke. Pours a dark brown/black appearance with a lasting dark brown head. Big roasty dark chocolate, coffee, burnt malty, light vanilla, pretty hoppy aroma. Fairly piney, light minty, dark chocolate, coffee, somewhat caramel, somewhat spicy flavor. Kick ass brew.

Bottled sample via and shared with oakbluff. Dark brown in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of dark chocolate, roasted malt, a bit of caramel and minerals. A great blend of flavors in the mouth with notes of pale and caramel malt, more chocolate and minerals, along with a bit of oat and some subtle pine all coming together. Medium bodied with a toasty and slightly chalky finish. Very solid overall.

A - Pours a dark black with a finger of chocolate colored frothy head atop. The head fades fairly slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of roasted dark chocolate malts, coffee, some citrus and earthy hops, and a bit of lactose sweetness.

T - Starts off with a mix of roasted chocolate malts with some light citrus hops and a bit of lactose sweetness. Through the middle, some coffee comes through with a touch of molasses, some earthy hops, and a touch of black licorice. The finish is a mix of dark chocolate malts, roasted coffee, earthy hops, black licorice, and a touch of lactose sweetness.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry, roasted, and lightly sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. Really nicely balanced porter. Just the right body and a great balance of malts.

16.9oz bottle from Liquor Stop in Tyngsborough, MA -- bottled 11/25/12 (freshness!).  Pours near-black with a moderate beige head.  Cocoa and caramel fill the nose, just as chocolate overwhelms the taste buds.  The "chewy" description fits, as this is a very rich, robust porter. Oats provide a smooth velvety mouthfeel, rounding out this great porter.

Bottle.  Pours a deep brown to black with a fairly large dense tan head.  Lots of lovely roast on the nose, cocoa and chocolate.  Medium bodied, super smooth a good amount of cocoa and even the faintest wood notes.  Lots of roast and cocoa.  Remarkably smooth, super easy drinking.  Long roast filled finish with just a touch of smoke.  Another lovely beer from these folks.

Pours a solid dark brown/black with a huge fluffy khaki colored head that persists forever. Smells of roast and chocolate with hints of caramel and earthy spicy hops and a bit of mineral and ash to round it all out. The flavor is rich with lots of bitter dark chocolate and hints of roast and caramel. Theres enough earthy hops to provide some balance and some nice flavors with little harsh bitterness. Medium to thick body with a light level of carbonation and a creamy roasty chalky mouthfeel. This is a very nice porter, I really enjoyed it! If only it were easier to find and at a lower price point these would fill my fridge!

Bottle brought to Franks after Capones Black Fri event 2012. Pours a deep brownish body with nice tan head. Aroma is cocoa, light toffee, toasted malts and light hop. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of chocolate malts, fresh hops and cocoa. Another solid beer from MBC.

Bottle.  Pours black with thick light brown mocha head.  Looks more like a stout than a porter.  Hoppy nose - pine and citrus, chocolate, toffee.  Taste is chocolate, dark roasted malts, some pine.  Good.

50cl bottle pours a murky black with some creamy, beige head.  Nose of molasses, burnt caramel, a little rubber, bread.  Flavor is sweet, malty, brown sugar, caramel, burnt toast, plum.  Full, toasty finish.
Pours dark brown with small tan head and some lace. Aromas are roast malts, dark chocolate. Taste is roast malts, bitter chocolate, dark coffee. Full body, dry, bitter chocolate finish.

[bottle from HP Provisions]
Toasty coffee  malt aroma with a touch of vanilla and a faint pumpernickel accent. Opaque brown with clear ruby-brown highlights under a ruddy, light brown blanket that lasts and laces the glass. Full toasty pumpernickel and tangy semi-sweet chocolate flavour with vanilla coffee and faint dried fruit. Full body, moderate to medium carbonation, tangy chocolate finish. Balance is on the sweet side, but the tang and a gentle bitterness are providing a decent amount of balance.

Dark brown black with a medium sized, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of roasted malts, burnt wood, chocolate, some dark fruits, and a bit of vanilla bean. Taste of roast, dark chocolate,some vanilla, a bit of smoke, and a dry, roasty finish.

Bottle compliments of Dallas shared with some dudes after the Black Fri event. Dark brown pour with medium tan head. Aromas of centennial, cocoa, toffee, and some roasted malts. Taste most of the same. A nice hoppy porter from Maine.

Bottle poured a dark brown with a medium light brown head and notable lacing.  Aroma includes significant dark chocolate and roasted malt notes followed by slight smoke.  Taste begins with roasted malt, coffee, and smoke before a smooth dark chocolate finish.  Very drinkable with complex flavors lingering.

Bottle thanks to FooFaa, pours a dark brown/black with a medium tan head. Aroma of chocolate, earthy bitter coffee, caramel, a nice level of hops, oats, roasted malts, and molasses. An earthy roasted bitterness envelops the taste buds, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, big hop presence, with caramel. A solid porter!

Ive enjoyed the majority of beers that Ive had from Maine brewing, so hearing that this was a part of a recent trade I was pretty excited.  Deep brown in color with a nice khaki head.  Looks promising.  Aroma has tobacco and chocolate.  Pretty damn hoppy for a porter.  Chocolate, light grapefruit, tobacco, and a dry finish.  Damn solid offering from Maine again.
Bottle from craft ale house. Pours pitch black with a thin film of tan on top. The aroma has some light coffee and dark chocolate. The taste is medium roast with a nice mocha trail. Awesome.

Bottle poured very dark brown with a nice thick one finger brown head. Aroma has chocolate, brown malt, and light hops poking through. Mouth feel is a hefty medium with lower side carbonation and a nice thick texture. Flavor has plenty of rich malt for a porter, chocolate, light coffee, and some faint hops.
Bottle. Poured a black color with an averaged sized than head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, pine, and floral. Tastes of roast, vanilla, pine, caramel, chocolate, and coffee.

Great local porter. These guys can be aggressive with there hops. This brew is towards the hoppy side of a porter but tamer than I thought it would be. Chewy and thick great brew to look at too. Ya I recommend it

500ml bottle. Pours dark brown with a creamy beige head. Another expensive yet thoroughly delicious offering from MBC. Nice chocolate and coffee flavors, silky mouthfeel, and an overall stout like dryness.

Not sure of the size on this because I dont see it on the bottle and the printing is really Goddamned small.  Im guessing about 500 cL.  Pours dark blackish brown with big fluffy, well-retained tan head.  Nose is roasty black patent and choc malts, big hops, cacao.  Tastes medium in palate heft, with choc and munich malts, hops, some sweetness from the cacao, and a complex roasty finish.  This one ends with a huge amount of lacing on the glass.  I even saw the Virgin Mary herself in the Brussels lace.
Pours a dark brown with a brown eggshell lacing. The aroma consists of coffee and vanilla. the flavor is bittersweet and astringent.
Draft.  Dark brownish maroon, tan head.  Aroma of dark milk chocolate on a subtle pine background.  Taste is smooth and rich coffee and chocolate.  Tasty stuff.

Draft at Churchkey. Rich, chocolate brown pour with a creamy beige head. Nose and flavor bring a lovely combination of creamy vanilla and chocolate sweetness, roasted bitterness, and dank, resinous evergreen hops. Velvety and smooth on the palate- surprised this is at the higher end of the porter spectrum for ABV. Another superb effort by Maine Beer Co.
bottle courtesy of chriso, enjoyed at CBW. Very nice porter, dark black pour, orangy tan head. Chocolate heavy aroma and flavor with medium roast. Dry stout like bitterness, very nice porter

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2013 My Bottom Line:
Toasted bread flavors meet coniferous hop resins in this portly Robust Porter with fruity edges.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A rich head of foam tops the blackness.
-Carbonation is soft and expansive.
-Sweetness makes this brew feel heavier than it is. The lax finish, where wet bread, coffee and roast dominate, accentuates this impression of heft.
-Hops arent super bright even though they are initially intense.
-Hop aroma is quite complex though, in the forest-y range (wood, leaves, resins).

Bottles.

A new MBC offering? Yea instant buy for me. Plus everyone loves gorillas. Like everything Maine does it is the dictionary definition of a classic style. A porter with deep dark body and tan head. Aroma of chocolate roasted with touch or coffee foam. Taste is mild sweet with pine bitter and coffee acridness. Body is full without being heavy. A beer I could drink for days.

500mL Bottle. Opaque chocolate sauce and burnt barbeque ends mash with fig jam and barrel char. Much silkier and lighter than the aroma lets on. A fluffy body brings a light lick of acid to a pretty big cocoa powder show. Earnest and clean, but seemingly a touch light on the dark malt complexity. Alcohols perk up a dry finish, that has a cottony sensation to it. The body seems light and airy for a 7.5% porter. Fantastic brewing no doubt, but maybe not the flavor-bomb show stopper Ive come to expect from Maine Beer Co.
Bottle thanks like. Pours black with very solid tan head that fades quick. Big roasty chocolate and hop aroma. Taste is very silky mouth with lots of fresh main beer co hop and nuts dome coco too.

Very dark brown, not black pour covered by an initially large, but fading beige head. Very hoppy nose - like anything coming from Maine Brewing Co it seems, where juicy citrus meets acidic oily resin and distort the burnt chocolate cake maltiness. The sharply acidic combination between the roasted malts and citric hops feel detrimental to the seemingly layered and deep malt complexity. As is always the case with this brewer, the palate feels round, filling with unfiltered goodness yet never hindering drinkability thanks to among other things, an engaging carbonation. Very bitter finish with plenty of citrusy, piney hops and fruity dark chocolate intricacies. While alcohol does not constitute a major factor, it felt to me like this beer, despite its many strong points, was too intense and not very balanced on the acidity/bitterness axis. Ill still try anything they put out, but am definitely looking far more toward the pale than dark ales.

500ml bottle from City Market Burlington.
Appearance : Pitch black with medium foamy and creamy head. Long head retention, lots of lacing.

Aroma : Rich roasted malt with lots of coffee and some chocolate. Resinous and piny hops.Oily hops with some coffee acidity. 

Taste : Rich and velvety roasted malt with notes of coffee and light chocolate. Resinous and piny hops. Finish is oily, resinous and roasty with some coffee and a bit more dark chocolate.

Palate : Nice soft carbonation. Silky malty mouthfeel.

Overall : Wow, really complex, really malty. Great coffee notes with light chocolate. Awesome look and awesome mouthfeel. Got a bit thinner as it warmed up but wow the richness it had during the first half hour. Awesome complex malts, nicely balanced by the hops, nice mouthfeel. Great persistency of the finish. World class stuff.

Pours mahogany tinged black into an English pint. Off-white head with excellent retention recedes leaving spider lacing. Chocolate and soy aromas. Thin with sweet milk chocolate and espresso front to back. Lasting charred espresso finish.

Beer looks great and pours a black thick pour.  Aroma is very hoppy with some milk chocolate, and light roast.  Taste is very black IPA with lots of citrus/grassy hops and a robust roasty chocolate porter finish.  Pretty good beer just dont expect traditional porter.

Poured from a bottle received from Lukaduke. Thanks! The pour is a dark brown with a khaki colored head of foam with good retention. The aroma has lots of roasty, dark chocolate, and bitter coffee notes. Its quite a delicious smelling beer. The freshness of it comes through in the hop presence as well. Taste has some dark bittering chocolate and coffee with some roasty notes on the backend. Maine Beer company makes some damn fine beers. Really wish I had this stuff at home.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2012 Ultra fresh bottle.   Aroma of big potent milk chocolate,  dusty cocoa,  vanilla beans.  Taste is deep dark roasty dark chocolate balanced nicely by a clean deep molasses, cocoa. Touch of grapefruit hops and complexity.   fudge brownies as it warms.     Awesome.   What a beer!

Thick, black pour with brown edges and a healthy tan head.  Aroma is bittersweet chocolate, a touch of roast, brownie batter, and a bit of coffee.  Chewy, silky in the mouth - Dry and rich, not overly sweet.  Dark chocolate abounds, earthy with a rich coffee roast finish.  Delicious.

Pours a deep umber color with a two finger mocha head that laces and settles... Aromas are a bit subtle but roasty malts, chocolate and a hint of grassy hops.  The mouthfeel is rich and smooth with nice bubbles to lighten it up. Flavors are roasted dark chocolate playing well off a big hoppy grassy citrusy notes... nice beer ad a welcome addition to Maine Beer line up.

Pours black with a medium dark mocha head.  Aroma has bitter dark chocolate, light nuttiness, and some hoppy bitterness.  Flavor has nice piney hop notes, some burnt notes, bitter espresso, and dark chocolate.  Mouthfeel is full and the finish is roasty/burnt,piney...almost like a black ipa.
